Comments_List: I gained a much better idea of how I will go about conducting research for and writing my final project. I improved my ability to read critically and extract information from texts.
From this course I gained a better understanding about what exactly constitutes African American Studies and how to think, read, and write like an African Americanist.

1. A clearer understanding of my senior project
2. How to understand methodological frameworks that underpin intellectual pieces on race
3. The myriad of research tools available on campus for students
4. How to think critically about theory

One of the biggest strengths was that we took time out of class to evaluate and cover everybody's projects. It was incredibly collaborative within the classroom, and the professor was very good at curating conversations within the classroom.
The strengths of this course were the syllabus and Professor Reed.

Strengths: Incredibly knowledgeable professor, engaging and diverse readings, most course flexibility I have ever seen in a class at Yale

Weaknesses: Only once a week, classmates could make it through without reading so we did not get to deeply engage with some texts as I would have liked
Great course, amazing to be in a class with your major, glad AfAm does this.
I would recommend this class to another student. Even if you're aren't an AFAM major there's a lot that someone could derive from this class.
I would strongly recommend this course to any student who is interested in African American Studies, even those who don't major in it.

Yes, even if you are outside the major. I just found the material incredibly helpful for understanding the evolution of some debates in the African American Studies field, and I really enjoyed a small seminar with everyone that was similarly interested in these topics.
